Lou Lieberman; the deputy chairman, Harry Quick; my Labor colleagues, Daryl Melham, the shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, and Warren Snowdon, the member for the Northern Territory; my Liberal colleagues, Barry Haase, the member for Kalgoorlie, Barry Wakelin, the member for Grey, Trish Draper, the member for Makinâand my only other female colleague on that committeeâand Jim Lloyd, the member for Robertson; and my National colleague, Bob Katter, the member for Kennedy.
I applaud this report and I hope the minister acts on the recommendations in it. I hope it will continue to further the steps towards true reconciliation in our country.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to bring the attention of the Main Committee to Unlocking the Future: The report of the inquiry into the Reeves Review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 , produced by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. John Reeves QC was appointed by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator John Herron, in October 1997 to conduct a review of the act. On 20 August 1998, Reeves presented his report. Having read the report and, as a member of the committee, hearing evidence from Mr Reeves, I was impressed by the degree of goodwill, depth of understanding, sound reasoning and rational recommendations demonstrated. I was surprised, therefore, by the general lack of backing for the report exhibited by the many witnesses and written submissions before the committee.

speech.para: Reeves's review was the first carried out since 1983 and, given that much had changed since 1976, a review was necessary. About 42 per cent of the Northern Territory has now been granted to Aboriginal land trusts for the benefit of Aboriginal people. So a great deal of the purpose for which the act was drafted has been achieved. In short, a fresh view was justified.

Many will say, `If it ain't broke, don't fix it', and we are all reluctant to change. However, there exists in the Northern Territory, and in communities across Australia, ample evidence to suggest that existing legislation is not working. Far too many legislators, and their city based constituents, are of the opinion that the much publicised funding being directed to our Aboriginal communities is now solving the problem. A general and pathetic misguided view is, in fact, that Aboriginal people receive too much.

The truth is that most remote Aboriginal populations endure substandard housing, suffer a higher level of illness, die younger, achieve a lower level of literacy and numeracy, have a higher per capita involvement in substance abuse, have a greater incidence of domestic violence and enjoy almost no opportunity for real employment by comparison with city based mainstream populations. And, in most practical terms, they have no choice. You may well ask, `Why?' And that may, for many of my city based colleagues, be the first step to finding a solution, because the first step to finding a solution is to accept that there is a problem.

Quite clearly, in the process of collecting evidence for his report, Mr Reeves heard many complaints against the existing act and his attention was directed to aspects that needed change. Amongst the evidence he heard, Mr Robert Lee of the Jawoyn Association said:

We want to plan wisely to ensure the maximum benefit for all for the land for the people, both black and white. Careful planning is the key to it all. We don't want to rush into anything because we know that unplanned development has a habit of costing money and wasting our time. We are just not interested in quick and easy ways of making money. We have addressed above changes in the Act that would improve the ability for Aboriginal people in achieving economic development objectives.
Further, Mr John Liddle of the Central Australian Aboriginal Congress said:

However, more and more, we would hope and expect to see their focus move towards supporting economic independence and community development of our people. Specifically we would hope to see the Land Councils foster an appropriate range of approaches to local self-government, assist communities in planning development, advise and support Aboriginal groups who want to establish small scale local businesses. Again, an experimental approach is necessary, as there is no established simple solution to developing their economic self-reliance of their communities.
The Northern Territory Labor Party said:

The need for Aboriginal traditional owners to have opportunities for economic development is of critical importance so that they may be able to break away from welfare dependency and enjoy the standards of living that others are able to. Many Aboriginal Territorians are keen to utilise their land as a means of economic developmentâthough we recognise and support those who do not wish to do so.
As a result, amongst other points, Reeves recommended that the act be amended:
. to encourage the formation of a partnership between Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory and the Government and people of the Northern Territory;
. to provide Aboriginal people with effective control over decisions in relation to their lands, their communities and their lives; and
. to provide opportunities for the social and economic advancement of Aboriginal peoples in the Northern Territory.

This cameo of evidence and rational recommendation is typical of the Reeves report, and yet when the committee, of which I am a part, travelled extensively and heard many hours of evidence, very little support for Reeves was forthcoming.

My point is the great difficulty in containing consensus of opinion. Over a period of time, that opinion is dynamic, and perception of problems and solutions will be tempered by personal status and circumstances. I suggest the Reeves report was not well understood by the very people it was designed to assist, that those most affected by the proposed changes were in a position to most alter people's perception of the changes and that, even though evidence was invited from many and diverse parties, the witnesses we heard were well informed of only the contentious recommendations of the report.

Of the 45 recommendations made by the committee in our report Unlocking the Future, many are at odds with the Reeves report. The most notable example is perhaps the issue of regional land councils. Reeves proposed 18 councils instead of the existing four. Even though much criticism was made of the lack of autonomy, poor communications, infrequent contact, selective funding and insufficient representation, support for the creation of 18 smaller, more representative councils was minimal. This apparent contradiction was, for me, the main motivation to readily agree with our recommendation No. 2 regarding the establishment of project teams to consult and advise on issues where our recommendation has proposed more than one option. We recommended that such a team be put together as a representative group at the discretion of the minister to communicate widely on a particular topic, a final decision being made only with the informed consent of traditional owners.

The establishment of new, more representative land councils is already accommodated under section 21 of the act. However, we have made recommendations detailing a process that will facilitate such action, including a plebiscite and informed consent of traditional owners.

When the act was first mooted, many Aboriginal people saw such legislation as the ultimate goalâthe panacea for all ills. With the passage of the act and the subsequent establishment of ATSIC, some people have had their expectations realised, but in the main they are individuals and family who have used position, popularity or education to secure a power base excluding the grassroots population. This results in the majority feeling cheated and, in some cases, worse off because their expectations were so great.

To appreciate the opportunities advanced by this report, attention should be paid to the core principles. The committee agreed that Aboriginal people should have the right to manage their land in any way they see fit, with the administration system most appropriate. Further support and encouragement should facilitate lease arrangements to individuals to provide employment opportunities and a diversity of land use.

The greatest opportunities and future choice will come not from land rights but from education. This is the single most empowering factor for all people. According to Dr Quentin Beresford, Senior Lecturer in Government and Politics at Enid Cowan University, in an address to the Social Education of Australia Conference in September in Perth, the Northern Territory has the lowest rate of Aboriginal year 12 student participation in Australia. I do not believe this reflects the standard of educational opportunities available; rather, the degree to which Aboriginal populations pursue their cultural ties. The percentage of Aboriginal students completing year 12 in Western Australia was slightly better, at 19 per cent; and the Queensland percentage was much better, at 45 per cent.

To understand the correlation between adherence to cultural law and low secondary school graduation requires an appreciation of Aboriginal culture and the realisation that, when male students become men, coeducational classroom participation is most often seen as inappropriate. More consideration of adult education at secondary level is required, with necessary inducements for greater participation and more productive outcomes. It is only with universal education standards that Aboriginal communities will truly be empowered to compete in mainstream Australia and enjoy the choices we all take for granted.

If our recommendations for changes to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 can facilitate a foundation on which secure communities can avail themselves of appropriately facilitated education services then, in keeping with the aspirations of Jon Altman of the Centre of Aboriginal Policy Research, we will have made recommendations for law reform that constitute good public policy.

My thanks to the committee chairman, the Hon. Lou Lieberman; to my committee colleagues; and to the incredibly resilient secretariat of James Catchpole, Claressa Surtees and Sara Cousins. I recommend this report to the chamber.

talk.start.para: âI, too, welcome the recent report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs titled Unlocking the future: the report of the inquiry into the Reeves review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 . I commend to the House the work of the standing committee and the staff who assisted them in conducting this inquiry. I also commend all the members of this committee who were committed to a bipartisan approach to the issue of Aboriginal land rights.

speech.para: The history of indigenous land rights in Australia is one that is fraught with tension. It is an issue that has caused much debate. Over 72 submissions were made to the committee by indigenous groupsâland councils, individuals, legal experts, the Northern Territory government and others. The committee also travelled widely across Australia to make contact with indigenous groups, land councils and individuals who are affected by the act. Unlocking the future is important because the recommendations set a precedent in that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are to give their consent on any land rights issues. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders will have the right to make the hard decisions on how their land is to be used.

The recommendations in the committee's report are positive because they take into account the need to alter the relationship between government and indigenous Australians to make it more consultative and open. As my colleague the member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon, said in the House on 30 August of this year:

The message to the parliament and government from the report is clear. The way ahead requires dialogue, consultation and negotiation between governments and indigenous Australians. There must be a new attempt at building a partnership between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. This report and its recommendations challenge the government to adopt a new and radically different approach to dealing with indigenous Australians.

The member for the Northern Territory is right. This report is a step in the right direction because it involves indigenous Australians in decision making. It is a welcome change from non-indigenous Australians deciding, in essence, what is best for indigenous Australians. What is also important to note about the report is that the committee makes recommendations that reject changes advocated by John Reeves QC in his report, Building on land rights for the next generation: the review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 .

The changes advocated in the Reeves review include: the recommendation to replace existing land councils with 18 regional land councils; the recommendation to replace the current permit system to enter Aboriginal land with an amended Northern Territory Trespass Act 1987; and the repeal of section 74 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.

The Reeves recommendations fundamentally deny indigenous Australians the right to make choices about their land and its uses. This denial of their rights is completely inappropriate. The Reeves review is a complete joke. It has been said in this Houseâand I will say it againâthat the Reeves review is a disgraceful waste of $1.3 million of the long-suffering taxpayers' money. The Reeves review was a political stunt fanned by Shane Stone and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in an attempt to remove land councils and weaken the land rights act. If implemented, the Reeves review would, of course, have caused the further social, economic and cultural degradation of indigenous communities in the Northern Territory. It would have broken the spirit of Aboriginal people across Australia. The committee has done a tremendous job in undoing much of the damage done by the Reeves review, and it must be commended for that.

I now wish to turn to the other recommendations in the committee's report which I believe are important in improving that part of the act dealing with the rights of the traditional landowners. Firstly, I refer to the recommendations pertaining to land councils. Several of the recommendations explicitly set down the correct process in which land councils requiring formation are given explicit instructions on formation to ensure that a 60 per cent majority of Aboriginal people support the formation. In particular, I support recommendation 10 which ensures that land use agreements cover such matters as: resource development, service delivery arrangements, access to housing, and leasing of land for infrastructure. Recommendation 10 also empowers traditional Aboriginal landowners to accomplish this without the requirement of consent by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.

The committee also recognised that traditional Aboriginal owners do have the right to represent their own interests in land without land council involvement. Indigenous people have been allowed the right to make autonomous decisions within the recommendations in the committee's report.

I now refer to the recommendations regarding the mining provisions of the act. Of great importance is the recommendation that traditional Aboriginal owners, through their land councils, should have the right to withhold consent for any exploration or mining proposal, subject to current provisions of the act. These provisions are, firstly, that the Governor-General may override a refusal only if it is seen to be in the national interest; and, secondly, if mineral exploration has already been consented to, traditional owners are not able to withhold consent for mining. The rights of traditional owners are further protected if the Northern Territory minister for mining believes that the company is not negotiating in good faith.

I also commend recommendation 35 that calls for land councils to initiate public awareness campaigns about the operation of the permit system, including its role in natural and cultural resource management. On 9 August 1999 I spoke in the House about the issue of indigenous employment. I mentioned the realisation of government that indigenous Australians must be involved at all levels in consultation and negotiation with governments. The committee has recognised this crucial issue to indigenous people in its report. If we as a nation are to achieve the goal of reconciliation, indigenous people must have their right to autonomous decisions as a community, especially where land rights are concerned. Again, I congratulate the committee on a first-class job in the interests of our indigenous brethren.
Debate (on motion by Dr Stone) adjourned.

debate.para: Motion (by Dr Stone) proposed:
That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak about the impact of the Howard government on education and in particular on education in regional Victoria. What a sad example we have of a government that could not do more to retard the progress of a country like Australia. Just as a brief example, since the Howard government came to office there has been some $800 million cut from education in total. University grants have been reduced by almost a billion dollarsâthat represents almost six per cent, and some 21,000 student places.

speech.para: There has been $500 million slashed from student income support. I do not have to tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, the difficulty that is going to place on students from poor Australian backgrounds. There has been $240 million cut from TAFE at a time when 35,000 extra students are missing out on TAFE positions every year. There has been $130 million cut from government schools, with $400 million slashed indirectly by reduced state grants.

In April 1997 the government announced $200 million for schools as part of the new Job Network. Not one dollar has been received by any schools in Australia since that announcement. In November 1997 the government claimed that its up-front fees policy would create some 90,000 new university places, but by the end of 1998 less than 800 students had enrolled in the full undergraduate places scheme. On top of all of that, in July next year we are going to have the impost of the GST on the education system.

The Howard government will increase the cost of education dramatically through the introduction of a GST. The only parts of the education sector free from this new 10 per cent tax are tuition fees and some boarding school fees. This is a major blow to the prospects of lifelong learning in Australia. It means that for the first time in this country's history the purchase of books will be taxed. The education of all Australian students, whether in school, TAFE or university, will be more expensive as the GST increases the price of books, newspapers, computer software, Internet use, clothes, uniforms and public transport. The GST represents a government schools tax as it will apply to many of the so-called voluntary contributions now levied in government schools. Non-tuition fees are not GST free.

For the average family with two children at a government school, the GST is likely to add $360 per annum to the cost of that schooling. Under the Howard government, schools, TAFEs and universities will have to pay a GST on all purchases and then claim back these expenses from the tax office. This will hurt the cash flow of each educational institution, plus add significantly to their administrative costs, leaving fewer resources available for education itself. A GST will apply to all adult community education courses. GST on community based education will dissuade many adult Australians from re-engaging in the benefits of education. The Howard government could not possibly inflict more damage on Australian institutions and education institutions if they tried. They are dealing with education with all of the compassion of the Third Reich.

I would like to highlight some of the problems we have experienced in Bendigo. For example, in Bendigo we have La Trobe University, a fine facility and ably led by Professor Les Kilmartin. It is an integral part of Bendigo's economy, but since the Howard government came to office there have been 150 jobs gone from that institution. That resulted in about $5 million being ripped out of Bendigo's economy. As I said, it is an integral part of Bendigo's economy and it just cannot survive with the sort of scheme that is being planned.

Deregulating fees will place education out of the reach of most regional Australians, especially those in Bendigo, the area that I represent. If you are battler, if you are on a single income of $35,000 or maybe $40,000 a year, you just will not able to afford to educate your families. The compounding problem is that there will be no limits on fees charged by universities. That means it is an open market. Universities will have to charge exorbitant fees to survive. We will see big differences between city and regional universities. The big universities in the metropolitan areas will survive but the regional universities will be starved of funds.

Compound interest rates applying to accumulated debt will ensure that the debt just keeps growing. Families that want to have higher education for their kids will experience extreme difficulties by having to pay compound interest rates for 25 or 30 years. As my colleague, the shadow minister for education has pointed out, the choice will be that you either buy a house or you buy an education for your kids. It is an appalling proposal, and the government should be condemned for even thinking about it.

talk.start.para: âI take this opportunity to relate to the House a situation that occupied my time for five days during the last parliamentary break. After a great deal of planning and coordination I was able to tour the communities of the Western Desert in the far eastern portion of Western Australia, in the main, above the 26th parallel. It is an area that is populated by approximately 3,000 Aboriginal people and a handful of Europeans.

speech.para: The planning that went into it was spread over a very long time. It was meant to take place back in March, but a good friend of mine and a close relative, who was to accompany me, was unable to make it then. His grandmother and my grandfather were brother and sister. He was to accompany me back in March, but he went and had a triple bypass instead, just to get out of the trip!

This gentleman's name is Noel Blythe. I recognise and pay tribute to him as being one of the most compassionate and understanding persons, and least critical of people, that I have probably ever met. He accompanied me on this five-day tour of some seven communities of the Ngaanyatjarra area of Western Australia. The communities we visited were Cosmo Newbery, Tjirrkarli, Patjar, Warburton, Jamieson, Blackstone and Warrakurna, which is adjacent to the Giles weather station.

During those five days I witnessed some tragic situations. In two of the communities I visited there were recent deaths, and in the communities there was a very populous sorry camp in progress. I visited those sorry camps and commiserated with the bereaved. It was a tragic experience. These people are extremely traditional in their ways. Many of them will spend three weeks living in dreadful conditions with no regular water or food or sanitation, living more in the earth than on the earth during their mourning process.

It is an experience that certainly leaves one moved. Even though I would like all Australians to be well aware of the experience and the conditions, it is not one that I would wish upon them. I would wish, however, that hard-working people like Damien McLean, assisted by Keith Noble, both from the Warburton community, continue to find the strength of character and the time and dedication to continue good works amongst these Aboriginal people and their communities. They are there to assist where possible, to direct, and to come up with the visions spanning that great gulf between mainstream civilisation, as we call it, and what is a traditional way of life.

It is only with people like that, and the very knowledgeable and well experienced people like Noel Blythe of the Christian Alliance Church, with his 40 years experience, that we will see a future for Aboriginal people and a true reconciliation with mainstream Australia.

talk.start.para: âIt is with a great deal of concern that I raise in this chamber the quite atrocious behaviour of G. and K. O'Connor Abattoirs of Pakenham in my electorate. In particular, I raise concern about the role that the federal government have played in a disgusting, sickening lockout which some 160 workers at that abattoir have just endured for the last eight months.

speech.para: G. and K. O'Connor are a large employer in Pakenham. They have been involved in this aggressive lockout for getting on to seven or eight months now. There has just been a development of sorts in that around 30 of the workers at G. and K. O'Connor, having been bludgeoned by the company over the last six or seven months, have gone back under an Australian workplace agreement. They are going back having to put up with salary cuts ranging from around $60 a week to $300 a week. They are going back having to work probably an extra 45 minutes or an hour a day. They are going back having given up RDOs. They are going back having forgone quite an amount of sick leave.

Security disappears in this sort of environment. These people no longer have the security of employment which they need around which to build a good and decent life and to raise a family and make a contribution in our community. This is the type of environment that Peter Reith's legislation promotes and encourages. This is the type of situation where Peter Reith moves from being a minister acting on behalf of all Australians to being a minister who is acting in a partisan nature on behalf of the company and against the workers and the people of Pakenham and district.

I think it is useful to draw on the comments of the presiding Federal Court judge who was hearing this matter last week on 4 October. I will read out some of the transcript in the Federal Court. In relation to the lockout, acting on behalf of G. and K. O'Connor, Dr Jessup says:
This is a fairly unsophisticated one; it's an all or nothing . . .
Judge Spender says:
Yes. This is a baseball bat lockout.
Dr Jessup says:
It is sort of, your Honour, yes.
Judge Spender says:
Pinkertons Incorporated.

I do not know whether everyone in this chamber understands the significance of what Judge Spender has just said. Those of you with a bit of knowledge of labour history, and in particular American labour movement history, would understand the significance of Judge Spender's comments referring to the behaviour of G. and K. O'Connor, which has taken place under Peter Reith's legislation, by referring to it as being similar to the actions taken in the past by Pinkertons Inc.

Pinkertons Inc. was a notorious US detective company which acted as an anti-union operation in that country for a number of years. They used to infiltrate US labour movement activities. They used to be involved in kidnapping, violence towards union members, extortion, vandalism, and a battery of other illegal and improper activities. So a judge of the Federal Court in Victoria is referring to action being taken by a company, G. and K. O'Connor, as being similar to the illegal and immoral actions which were taken by Pinkertons Inc. in the United States.

I mention again that this action is being taken under the legislation of Peter Reith, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. I think people opposite should be ashamed that this sort of legislation promotes and encourages Pinkertons Inc. type of behaviourâthe type of behaviour which is illegal and immoral and destroys communities such as those that exist in my electorate: in this case the Pakenham district. I stand by the workers at G. and K. O'Connor Abattoirs, as does everyone in the labour movement and everyone in the Labor Party. G. and K. O'Connor Abattoirs should be ashamed of themselves. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to make a few comments about the recently tabled report of the inquiry into the Reeves review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 entitled Unlocking the future . Firstly, may Iânot out of simple courtesy, but out of actual genuine heartfelt beliefârecognise the contributions made by the chairman Lou Lieberman, deputy chairman Harry Quick, the committee staff, Hansard people and members of the RAAF, who could not be left out. I must say that I thought the commitment made by all members to this report was outstanding. When you consider that we had to cover a vast area like the Northern Territory, I thought the rollcall was absolutely outstanding and highlighted the interest and commitment of the committee to the task at hand.

speech.para: We were confronted with a fairly complex series of issues, which no doubt other members have covered in their contributions. For me the leading issue was the balance of rights between traditional owners and all other people, including those who might have an interest in the land in whatever form. It is that absoluteâ`clash' I think is too strong a wordâcompetition between the cultures which was foremost in my mind, and you saw it on the ground every time you visited the various communities.

Whilst respecting very much the traditional owners, I felt particularly strongly for those Aboriginal people who were not regarded as traditional owners and for a whole range of people of the Territoryâthe European settlersâin relation to how their land rights were to be protected. I also felt for the Northern Territory government, which has had great difficulties and unique issues compared with the rest of Australia because land rights cover 50 per cent of the land mass in the Northern Territory. It is not an issue that dominates the rest of Australia; it is not an issue that most Australians would be familiar with. So I have some empathy with the Northern Territory parliament and how it endeavours to deal with these issues.

The balance of rights issue which Mr Reeves QC grappled with on behalf of the minister was very interesting and challenging. I would really like to acknowledge the work of John Reeves. In the evidence that he gave to the committee in the last few days that the committee took public evidence in Darwin, I thought he summed up as well as any of the public evidence that Hansard recorded the focus that we need to have on the post land rights periodâthat is, the whole issue of land rights fought for and won over the last 30 years or more was drawing to a close. The Hawke government had made it quite clear in the sunset legislation that this period was drawing to a close in a practical way, and the role of the land commissioner in allocating the final areas has only a year or two to run.

This whole period of how we move from the fight for land rights into a more stable period, if you like, where perhaps the welfare dependency issue could be tackled more and where the bureaucracy of the land councils needed to be addressed was a very useful part of the whole exercise. In conclusion, the equity between taxpayer and the Aboriginal benefit trust reserve was an issue that I thought the committee did offer positive leadership on.

talk.start.para: âOctober is Breast Cancer Awareness Month and it gives me a great opportunity today to talk about a wonderful and inspiring group here in the ACT called Bosom Buddies. I am sure you would agree that is a great name for a group of women who support each other through their experiences with breast cancer.

speech.para: The group commenced in 1995 with four women meeting over coffee, and membership has grown steadily now to over 200. Women who have survived breast cancer will tell you that the journey begins with the diagnosis and on the journey they have to confront themselves physically, psychologically, emotionally and spiritually. Information is needed to demystify the strange and fearful world that women with breast cancer face. When a woman is diagnosed with breast cancer, her life changes fastâfacing surgery and treatment also means facing fears on many levels.

Bosom Buddies are just what their name saysâthey are there for women to be able to discuss what is going to happen, to reassure them and to give them hope afterwards. It is also a social and friendly support group and offers a range of activities to suit most interests. Some of the more fun groups that they involve themselves with include craft groups, dinner outings, a breakfast group, fun runs, a young mothers group and so on. They have also held workshops and seminars on many topics, including nutrition, skin care, aromatherapy, prosthesis and so on. In the past, a group of around 20 women entered the Canberra Times fun run. There is also a mobile phone and roster system of Bosom Buddies members who are available to listen to people at night when their fears are greatest. After being trained as volunteers, they speak to students in years 11 and 12 about breast self-examination and breast cancer generally, and the talks are personalised from the women's own experiences.

One of the biggest events each year is a fashion event. I have been to the last three or four of them and I had the pleasure of going to this year's fashion event last night. It is an amazing thing to attend. There were 850 or more people in the audience. It was an enormous function. The highlight, of course, is the fact that the models are women who have survived breast cancer. They model garments from nightwear and swimwear through to the most wonderful evening glamour gowns: nothing can be more inspiring than to see these women strutting the catwalk.

Last night, the youngest in the parade was in her 30s; she is a mother of twins still under a year old. The eldest was a 78-year-old; she appeared for the fourth year in a row and is the star of the show. The parade is put together under the coordination of Norma Bradley. I would like to read the names of the people who participated last night. They have all had a dramatic experience with breast cancer and can now stand proudly in front of the community: Aine Austin, Libby Ciuffetelli, Margaret Dando, Marie Devlin, Dot Feeneyâthe 78-year-old, Kerry Glover, Marie Higgs, Dee Knott, Jan Murphy, Maggie Sharp, Jackie Stuart and Marilyn Ward. All of these people were supported in the background by Joyce Gore, Michelle Heine and Rachel Kavanagh, amongst many others.

I understand that the President of Bosom Buddies in Canberra, Valerie Lee, and one of her colleagues, Anna Wellings-Booth, have a presence on the National Breast Council of Australia and represent the ACT views of these women at that level. I cannot stress the work of this group enough. One of the other wonderful projects that they have undertaken which has become quite famous is a photographic exhibition by Heide Smith, a very well-known photographer in these parts. The first exhibition was held two years ago and contained some of the most stunning photos of womenâin some cases with their families and childrenâall of whom were survivors of breast cancer. I understand that, if it has not already been done, a book is going to be published in order to raise more funds.

I can only commend very heartily the work of these people. They have had enough to contend with without having to support the rest of the community, yet they do. But with no reflection on men, women are so good at doing these sorts of things. I want to thank Jill Haidon, a personal friend of mine, who in fact introduced me, through her experience, to Bosom Buddies a few years ago. I can only stand and applaud, and actually be in awe of, her example, and the example of others.

talk.start.para: âThis week, as I am sure most members are aware, is Asthma Week. Members may also be aware that I am working with the National Asthma Campaign, as secretary of the health and aged care government policy committee, to form a National Asthma Campaign parliamentary group to support the work being done in this very important area. I am also proud to be part of a government which has accorded a very high priority to asthma, its treatment and its prevention.

speech.para: In fact, I will be competing in a five-kilometre race in support of the national awareness of asthma, against the member for Banks, Daryl Melham, the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, who will be running in support of the National Heart Foundation. I have a fact sheet here which I would like to read into Hansard, which talks about the problems, what asthma is and how we can have effective intervention.

Asthma is a major health problem for Australians, particularly our children. The personal, social and economic costs associated with the disease are high. The prevalence of asthma has increased in recent years and there are signs that asthma is becoming more severe. More than two million, or 11 per cent, of Australians have asthma, including one in four primary school children, one in seven teenagers and one in 10 adults. Asthma places a considerable burden on the health system, with the total health system costs for 1993-94 estimated at $477 million.

In 1995-96 asthma was the most common reason for hospital admission among those of school age and younger, while across all ages it ranked seventh. Asthma is also one of the 10 most common reasons for seeing a general practitioner. Deaths from asthma have been steadily decreasing from a peak of 964 deaths in 1989 to 715 deaths in 1997. This reflects the ongoing effectiveness of public education campaigns and asthma education efforts. However, there is evidence that suggests that up to 60 per cent of asthma deaths may be associated with avoidable factors.

Asthma is an inflammatory disease of the air passages, making them prone to narrowing and increased mucus production. It becomes difficult to move air in and out of the lungs. Symptoms include wheeze, shortness of breath, chest tightness and cough. Asthma is also a chronic condition with attacks occurring at varying intervals and with varying degrees of severity. Over many years, persistent asthma may cause permanent narrowing of the airways, resulting in reduced response to available treatments. Severe acute attacks can result in death. The underlying causes of asthma are not known. However, asthma may be triggered by exercise, house dust mite, pollens, cold weather, throat and chest infections, tobacco smoke and other factors.

Asthma is more common among those with other allergic symptoms such as hay fever and eczema; those with an asthmatic parent; those who have had a severe chest illness in infancy; and those infants whose mothers smoked during pregnancy. The exact causes of asthma are not yet known, and there is no cure. However, for most people with asthma, the condition can be successfully managed. Effective asthma management is aimed at achieving the best quality of life for the person with asthma, reducing ill health and deaths, and preventing the development of permanent abnormal lung function.

The National Asthma Campaign's six step asthma management plan, which is developed with a doctor, is aimed at helping keep people as free from asthma symptoms as possible. The main criteria are to know how severe your asthma is, achieve your best lung function, avoid asthma triggers, stay at your best with medication, have a written asthma action plan and check your asthma regularly. A written asthma plan helps many people with asthma and is developed in consultation with a medical practitioner. It sets out the correct doses of medications, what to do when asthma worsens, when to increase medication and when to get help. Progress needs to be checked regularly by a medical practitioner.

Not only is this National Asthma Week, but as the honourable member for Canberra stated earlier, it is also Breast Cancer Awareness Month. I would also like to note that tomorrow, Friday 15 October 1999, is Cystic Fibrosis National Day. I have received a letter from Mr Terry Stewart, the CEO, asking if I could wear a red rose ribbon in support of cystic fibrosis, and I am delighted to note, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you also have on a red rose ribbon today in support of Cystic Fibrosis National Day tomorrow.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 12 August 1999:

question.para: (1) What are the circumstances under which a retired individual or couple can access an approved long-dated or lifetime annuity and still claim the age pension.
(2) Is it possible for an individual with $100,000 in assets, apart from the family home, to invest in a complying income stream and still claim the full age pension.
(3) Is it possible for a couple who retire with $500,000 in superannuation to invest $200,000 in a qualifying annuity and still qualify for a part age pension.
(4) If sums invested in qualifying annuities have been excluded from the means test is there a limit on the amount that can be invested.
(5) If there is no limit on the amount that can be invested in a complying annuity, can a couple invest (a) $300,000, (b) $500,000, (c) $700,000 or (d) $1m and still qualify for a part pension.
(6) Are tests carried out before approving companies or individuals to provide long-dated annuities; if so, what.
(7) Are large income earners who pay little or no tax in Australia able to be major equity holders in companies that provide long-dated annuities.
(8) What impact will the new rules have on the number of persons receiving the age pension.
(9) Did the Minister state that she does not want to see $1,000,000 retirees on the age pension; if so, what assurances can the Minister give that this is not occurring.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Retired individuals who hold an approved lifetime or long dated annuity, can successfully claim the age pension providing they meet the residency, age and means test requirements. These requirements can be found on the Centrelink Internet site at http://www.Centrelink.gov.au/
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.

(5) (a) (b) (c) and (d). Yes, providing they are otherwise qualified to receive payments under the income and assets test. The income and asset test limits can be found in the Centrelink Internet site at http://www.Centrelink.gov.au/

(6) The Treasurer has advised that paragraph 9(1)(d) of the Life Insurance Act 1995 (the Act) provides that a contract that provides for the payment of an annuity for a term not dependent on the continuance of human life but exceeding the term prescribed by the regulations constitutes a life insurance policy. The Life Insurance Regulations state that the prescribed term is ten years.

A consequence of the above provisions is that only registered life companies may issue annuities with a term greater than ten years. Further, registration of companies is undertaken by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority in accordance with the Act. Subsection 21(3) of the Act provides the grounds on which APRA may refuse to register a company as a life company.

(7) The Treasurer has advised that the Financial Sector (Shareholdings) Act 1998 restricts a person's (or company's) shareholding in a life insurance companies to 15 per cent of the voting capital. The Treasurer may approve a higher percentage limit on national interest grounds. Approval under the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 may also be required.

(8) It is not possible to accurately estimate the impact of the new rules on the number of customers who will receive age pension. The behavioural responses to the 20 September 1998 changes are complex and varied and cannot be modelled with any degree of accuracy. For that reason, no allowance has been built into the age pension forward estimates for changes in customer numbers arising from the 20 September 1998 initiative, beyond the estimated initial impact on existing customers.
(9) No. However, the Minister did express concern that financial planners were advertising that you could be a millionaire and still get a social security pension.
